Risk Categories:
High: Probability>60%
Moderate: Probability <= 60% and > 40%
Low: Probability <= 40%
Project Documentation

The financial pressure on the millennial generation is ever increasing. Credit scores are a valuable asset that everyone is trying to protect. With every credit check the credit bureau is adding negative weight to consumer’s credit scores. It is a vicious circle in which you must apply for credit to get credit and if you are not approved, your credit score is negativly impacted and you still do not have credit.

We have created an application using supervised machine learning to train a model with credit default data to determine the probability and classification (“default” vs “non-default”) of the user’s liability. By taking a user input that can be passed in as features in the model, we can predict the user’s likelihood to default, which can be equated to not qualifying for line of credit before a "hard pull" has been completed.

Data Explotation

The dataset comes from UC Irvine Machine Learning datasets. All monetary amounts are expressed in New Taiwan Dollars in 2005. We accepted this to be relevant for our model because 22% of accounts in the dataset show at least a 30 day default . According to the National Foundation for Credit Counseling "nearly 26 percent of Americans admit they do not pay their (credit card) bills on time, including people who sometimes miss a payment altogether(2009)." Default ratio is not dependent on geographical location.

Dataset contains 25 fields, including ID. All fields have been explained below.

Dataset MetaData
  • limit_bal:
    • Amount of the given credit (New Taiwan dollar)
  • sex:
    • (1 = male; 2 = female)
  • education:
    • (1 = graduate school; 2 = university; 3 = high school; 4 = others)
  • marriage:
    • (0 = null; 1 = married; 2 = single; 3 = others)
  • age
    • (years)
  • pay_1 - pay_6 : History of past payment. Past monthly payment records From April to September, 2005 as follows:
    • pay_1 = the repayment status in September, 2005
    ...
    pay_6 = the repayment status in April, 2005
    The measurement scale for the repayment status is:
    -1 = pay duly;
    1 = payment delay for one month
    2 = payment delay for two months
    ...
    9 = payment delay for nine months and above
  • bill_amt1-bill_amt5:
    • Amount of bill statement (NT dollar)
  • pay_amt1-pay_amt6:
    • Amount of previous payment (NT dollar)

Below we have visualized the data to understand the attributes and to make decisions on how to process the data

Feature Engineering

To properly utilize this dataset, we had to create time-independent variables from the fields that are measured over time. This would allow us to gather a user input from our application and apply that to our model. Here are the aggregations and changes that we made to the dataset before modeling:


  • Removed ID
  • Created Pay ‘Score’ Average (pay_score_avg), calculated the mean of individual accounts 6 month pay ‘score’
  • Created Average Payment Amount (pay_amt_avg), calculated the mean of individual accounts 6 month payment amount
  • Created Average Bill Amount(bill_amt_avg), calculated the mean of individual accounts 6 month bill amount
  • Created Credit Utilization, calculated by (bill_amt0/limit_bal)
  • Created Payment to Bill Percentage, calculated by (avg_pay_amt/avg_bill_amt)
  • Adjusted all monetary amounts to 2018 USD

Using the created features we visualized trends by Sex, Age, Marital Status and Education. We have included Age and Sex below.



Model Selection


Random Forest Feature Importance

After exploring and processing our data we began to determine the best machine learning model for this problem. Because we are classifying users by their potential to default or not default we are comparing Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and Neural Networks. We used Precision, Recall, F1 Score, and Confusion Matrix to rate our models.

To the left you can view the efficacy of the models using the Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) Curve of each model.

We are using the Random Forest model because it produced the highest F1 Score(0.78). Random Forest models can provide insight into the feature importance and the decision flow of determining a user’s future default status. The downside is that Random Forest and Decisions Trees can ‘over-fit’ the models, meaning the model cannot generalize, resulting in a model that isn’t receptive to new data. The ROC Graph shows that this model is not overfit but is producing the most accurate results.
